newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia appoints advisors to Islamic banking.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia appoints advisors to Islamic banking.

text.p: The central Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) said on Wednesday it has appointed 10 advisors to advise it on matters pertaining to Islamic banking and Islamic insurance.

The National Sharia Advisory Council for Islamic Banking and Takaful "will be the sole authoritive body to advise BNM on Sharia (Islamic law) issues pertaining to Islamic banking and takaful," the Bank said in a statement.
The council will review the compatibility with Islamic law any new Islamic products submitted by banks participating in Malaysia's interest-free banking scheme and by Islamic-insurance firms.
The body will also "harmonise the application of Islamic concepts for existing Islamic financial products", the statement said.
Malaysia aims to be a regional capital market centre including for Islamic financial products, with many financial institutions offering financial products which conform to Islamic law.
But there has been differences in opinions on issues among the various Islamic committees formed by the financial institutions.

"Although Islam places high regards to differences in views, differences in Sharia opinions which may affect the confidence of Moslems must be addressed so as to enable us to progress," Bank Negara said.
"Thus, the establishment of a single Sharia body at BNM is an important and crucial step to harmonise these differences," it added.

Among the advisors are Ahmad Ibrahim, deputy rector of International Islamic University Malaysia, Abdul Halim Ismail, chief executive officer of BIMB Securities and Ahmed Ali Abdalla, secretary-general of the Higher Sharia Consultaive Committee of the Bank of Sudan.
As at end-March, total deposits of the Islamic banking sector amounted to 9.1 billion ringgit, while financing mobilised totalled 6.9 billion ringgit.
The volume of Islamic interbank money market for the first three months amounted to 41.7 billion ringgit against 55.1 billion for the whole of 1996.
In the takaful industry, total assets at end-December stood at 295.6 million ringgit, of which family takaful constitutes 59.5 percent of total assets.
